Title.evidence: This study aimed to observe pupillary dilation reflex by ultrasound and determine whether ultrasonic pupillary parameters are correlated with sufentanil dose during the induction period of general anesthesia.

Trial_Design.evidence: They were randomly divided into 3 groups – group P (saline), group S1 (0.2 μg/kg sufentanil), and group S2 (0.4 μg/kg sufentanil) – according to the sufentanil dose of induction.

Participants.evidence: We enrolled 93 patients undergoing general anesthesia.

Intervention.evidence: They were randomly divided into 3 groups – group P (saline), group S1 (0.2 μg/kg sufentanil), and group S2 (0.4 μg/kg sufentanil) – according to the sufentanil dose of induction.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to observe pupillary dilation reflex by ultrasound and determine whether ultrasonic pupillary parameters are correlated with sufentanil dose during the induction period of general anesthesia.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Ultrasonic pupil diameters were recorded and measured at 4 time points: T0 (entering the room awake), T1 (after loss of consciousness), T2 (5 min after intravenous injection with sufentanil), and T3 (the moment at which pupil diameter was maximum after stimulation).

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: They were randomly divided into 3 groups – group P (saline), group S1 (0.2 μg/kg sufentanil), and group S2 (0.4 μg/kg sufentanil) – according to the sufentanil dose of induction.

Number_Randomised.evidence: We enrolled 93 patients undergoing general anesthesia.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Ultrasonic pupillary dilation reflex amplitude and pupillary dilation reflex rate were negatively correlated with sufentanil dose [Spearman r =−0.84 (95% CI, −0.88 to −0.77), p <0.01, Spearman r =−0.74, (95% CI, −0.82 to −0.64), p <0.01].
